block.p: AFTER THE SPACE SHUTTLE -- Lockheed Martin won a multibillion-dollar contract from NASA to build the nation's next spaceship for human flight. [Page A1.]

INDIA'S NEW ECONOMY -- For decades, India had followed a route to economic development strikingly different from the manufacturing and exporting economies of Japan, South Korea and China. But all that is starting to change. [A1.]

DETRACTORS IN CALIFORNIA -- California is once again at the forefront of the nation's environmental policy, with a sweeping pledge to curb carbon emissions by 2020. But the deal struck this week between the state's Democratic legislators and its Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, above, has divided California's business community. [C1.]

REPRIEVE FOR PLAVIX -- A federal judge in Manhattan ordered a Canadian company to stop distributing its generic version of the blockbuster anticlotting drug Plavix, granting a reprieve to Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, which co-market the brand-name drug. [C1.]
BUFFETT GETS MARRIED -- The marriage of Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, to his longtime companion had the financial world all aflutter, even if it did not move markets. [C1.]

BREAST-FEEDING DISPARITIES -- As the popularity of breast-feeding increases, a two-class system is emerging, with well-paid working mothers afforded flexibility, and lower-income mothers finding pumping at work nearly impossible. [A1.]
VILLAGE VOICE DISMISSES EIGHT -- The Village Voice, the New York alternative weekly, dismissed eight people, including its longtime pop music critic. [C5.]

CONSUMER SPENDING SURPRISE -- Spending by American consumers grew in July at twice the rate it did in June, suggesting that the economy may not be slowing as suddenly as some economists had thought. [C5.]
CANADA GOLD DEAL -- Goldcorp and Glamis Gold, two Canadian mining companies whose executives have clashed on other takeover deals, agreed to a friendly merger worth about $21.3 billion. [C5.]
TEENAGE MARKET BOOMING -- Retailers that specialize in merchandise for teenage customers reported sharply higher sales in August as young people flocked to malls ahead of the new school year. [C5.]
FORD EXPLORES SALE OF UNIT -- Ford said it was exploring a sale of all or part of Aston Martin, the British automaker. [C5.]

PLOT AS PITCH -- Six films on a Web site that is scheduled to go live today run 60 to 90 seconds each, about as long as it takes to brew a cup of espresso. It's no coincidence: the Web site is sponsored by Krups to promote a line of espresso makers. Advertising. Stuart Elliott. [C6.]
NEW NAME FOR CHIP MAKER -- The chip unit of Philips Electronics is adopting a new name, NXP, for ''Next Experience,'' as it becomes a stand-alone company. [C6.]

MORE SUBPOENAS FOR TAKE-TWO -- Take-Two Interactive Software, the embattled video game publisher, said it had received additional grand jury subpoenas from the Manhattan district attorney's office seeking information about its financial activities. It also said it planned to delay its fiscal third-quarter earnings report. [C6.]

RULES FOR MUNICIPAL PENSIONS -- The board that writes accounting rules for state, county and local governments said it was starting a project to improve cities' disclosure of information about the pension funds they run for municipal employees. [C8.]
SHARES TREAD WATER -- Wall Street ended an aimless session barely lower after investors shrugged off comments about productivity by the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke. [C8.]

CALL FOR DATA ON GAS PIPELINE -- The Department of Transportation said it needed more test data from BP's inspection of its Prudhoe Bay pipeline system in Alaska before it could approve the company's alternative plan to restart crude production there. [C8.]

THE H. J. HEINZ COMPANY POSTED a greater-than-expected 23 percent rise in quarterly profit, aided by higher prices and increased sales of new products. But the company also stood by its full-year forecast, rather than raising it, and Heinz shares fell. (REUTERS)

AN ELECTRONIC ARTS VIDEO GAME, Need for Speed Carbon, will have more than just gleaming sports cars and streets to race on when it is released in October: drivers will also speed past real-time advertisements for films, automobiles and other products. (AP)
